title: False start has Karoon running out of energy
text:
And, on closer inspection, it looks like that was very much Karoon’s intention.

The presentation released to the ASX was initially titled “Project Wilson – Karoon Equity Raise overview”, according to the document’s metadata, and was authored by a junior banker in Macquarie Capital’s Perth office.

So it appears Karoon and its bankers had intended to raise equity last week but, for whatever reason, got cold feet and pulled the pin. While there are many reasons why it could have been delayed – both good and bad – it’s much easier to envisage negative scenarios. Equity capital markets deals are usually pulled when there are fears about underlying demand, be it based on concerns of wall-crossed investors or seasoned ECM bankers fretting over market conditions.

Karoon has since filed an updated presentation on its own website, titled “Karoon Investor Review October 2019” and authored by the company’s corporate finance manager Al Gordon, to cover up what appears to be a monumental own goal.

The question fast money hedge funds are now asking is when will Karoon come to market – and how to trade around it? According to Karoon’s comprehensive October update, the deal is due to complete early in the new year and will be backdated to January 1, 2019.

Karoon said the $US665 million headline price would be reduced by $US150 million to $US180 million to account for 2019 production, while it had already paid a $US49.9 million deposit. It leaves about $U450 million to be paid – and $US250 million of that is already committed by Dutch bank ING as senior debt funding, with potential for more. Assuming Karoon will not want to drain all of its $US178 million in the bank, fundies expect about an equity raising worth more $200 million or more.
description: It’s 2½ months since Karoon Energy and its bankers warmed up fund managers for an equity raising.
